results.headline: Not a Happy Homecoming

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Here and There

results.summary_short: “Aquí y Allá” is about an immigrant’s return to his family in Mexico, with savings and a dream, and a difficult choice he soon faces.

results.headline: Paranoia From Both Left and Right
results.display_title: American Empire: An Act of Collective Madness

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Empire: An Act of Collective Madness

results.summary_short: Patrea Patrick’s “American Empire” posits that multinational corporations have created a “cartel economy” bent on world domination.

results.headline: Étude on Aging, Its Graces, Its Indignities

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amour

results.summary_short: A masterpiece about life, death and everything in between, Michael Haneke’s “Amour” is about an elderly French couple — played by two titans of French cinema — in their final days.

results.headline: On the Road, With Their Baggage

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Guilt Trip

results.summary_short: A mother and son, played by Barbra Streisand and Seth Rogen, set off on a drive across the country in “The Guilt Trip.”

results.headline: By Any Means Necessary

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zero Dark Thirty

results.summary_short: “Zero Dark Thirty” treads on unusual territory for moviegoers used to Hollywood’s practice of simplifying morality.

results.headline: Perseverance Reigns When Incurable Disease Strikes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jason Becker: Not Dead Yet

results.summary_short: A remarkable support network comes together in “Jason Becker: Not Dead Yet,” allowing a guitar guru to compose music using only his eyes.

results.headline: Ahead of Their Times, but Resolved to Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Any Day Now

results.summary_short: In “Any Day Now,” directed by Travis Fine, Alan Cumming plays a drag queen in 1979 who struggles to adopt an abandoned teenager with Down syndrome.

results.headline: A Mixed-Race Girl in a Mixed-Up World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yelling to the Sky

results.summary_short: In “Yelling to the Sky” a quiet teenager named Sweetness moves through a sometimes brutal life like a leaf caught on the wind.

results.headline: Gloom and Doom for the Planet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trashed

results.summary_short: “Trashed” is a down-and-dirty documentary about our inability to neutralize safely much of what we throw away.

results.headline: Bilbo Begins His Ring Cycle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey

results.summary_short: In Peter Jackson’s 3-D adaptation of “The Hobbit,” Bilbo sets out with the wizard Gandalf and a posse of dwarfs to battle a fearsome dragon.

results.headline: A Daughter Stumbling in Her Father’s Footsteps

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl

results.summary_short: In “The Girl” a woman follows her father’s career path and decides to start smuggling people into the United States on her own, with less success.

results.headline: In Gangster State of Mind: Aging? Fuhgeddaboutit

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stand Up Guys

results.summary_short: “Stand Up Guys” features veteran gangsters on a last rampage; you might describe the movie as a bad-boy “Bucket List.”

results.headline: From a Murder to Madness

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saving Grace B. Jones

results.summary_short: In “Saving Grace B. Jones,” directed by Connie Stevens, Tatum O’Neal plays a violent madwoman.

results.headline: Failure to Commit in a World Where Romance Rules

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Save The Date

results.summary_short: The heroine of “Save the Date” is cute and droll, but should a man dare to say he loves her, she shuts off.

results.headline: Fighting the Power Across the Globe and Time

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Let Fury Have The Hour

results.summary_short: “Let Fury Have the Hour” is a scrapbook of historical moments and progressive comments jostling for attention.

results.headline: Bones in the Woods, Family Secrets in the Heart

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Consuming Spirits

results.summary_short: “Consuming Spirits” is an inquiry into the darkest zones of the human heart and a wondrous piece of animated filmmaking.

results.headline: A New Orleans Odyssey

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tchoupitoulas

results.summary_short: Brothers in their teens, and their adventures in New Orleans, filmed by the brothers Bill and Turner Ross.

results.headline: Soccer Star Sinks Into a Matinee-Idol Mess

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Heleno

results.summary_short: “Heleno” follows the career of the 1940s Brazilian soccer star Heleno de Freitas and his decline from debonair womanizer to broken-down invalid.

results.headline: Daredevil Skateboarder and Marketer’s Dream

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Waiting For Lightning

results.summary_short: “Waiting for Lightning” is a documentary about the daredevil skateboarder Danny Way, famous for jumping over the Great Wall of China.

results.headline: Director Gleefully Tests the Limits of Free Expression

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sheik and I

results.summary_short: In the documentary “The Sheik and I,” the director Caveh Zahedi waves the freedom-of-speech flag in a major Arab emirate.
